questions.text: A 27-year-old man had an RTA resulting in the following gait abnormality. What is the largest part of the affected structure?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of post-traumatic cerebellar ataxia presenting with impaired balance. The largest part of the affected structure i.e. the cerebellum is the middle lobe, also known as the posterior lobe. The gait shown in the above video is a cerebellar ataxic gait. Here, the patient is seen attempting tandem walking and displaying improper heel-toe coordination, erratic foot placement, and truncal swaying.

The cerebellum consists of two hemispheres (right and left) joined by a median vermis. It is divided into three lobes:

  • Anterior lobe - lies superiorly above the primary fissure
  • Middle lobe - lies inferiorly below the primary fissure
  • Flocculonodular lobe - lies posterior to the uvulonodular fissure

It has two surfaces, superior and inferior, separated by a horizontal fissure. It is connected to the other parts of the central nervous system via three peduncles.

questions.text: Which of the following represents the arrangement of cerebellar nuclei from lateral to medial:
questions.solution: The arrangement of cerebellar nuclei from lateral to medial is dentate, emboliform, globose, and fastigial.

questions.text: The MRI report of a patient admitted with gait disturbances is given below. Phylogenetically, the oldest part of the atrophied structure is concerned with which nuclei?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cerebellar syndrome. Phylogenetically, the oldest part of the atrophied structure i.e. the cerebellum is archicerebellum/ vestibulocerebellum and it is concerned with fastigial nucleus (connected to vestibular nuclei via descending pathways along with medullary/pontine reticular formations).

questions.text: Cerebellar glomeruli are seen in which layer of the cerebellar cortex?
questions.solution:
Cerebellar glomeruli are seen in the granular layer (layer B) of the cerebellar cortex. 

Related Pearl: Layers of the cerebellar cortex

The cerebellar cortex is divided into 3 layers. They are:

  • Molecular layer - It is the outermost layer. It contains stellate cells and basket cells. They receive excitatory input from the parallel fibers and form inhibitory synapses on the Purkinje cells. It contains many myelinated and unmyelinated nerve fibers giving it a pale appearance in H and E staining.
  • Purkinje layer - It is the middle layer. It contain flask-shaped cell bodies of Purkinje cells. Their dendrites pass into the molecular layer. The axons of the Purkinje cells passes through the granular layer into the white matter and synapses with the cerebellar nuclei.
  • Granular layer - It is the innermost layer. It contains the cell bodies of the granule cells as well as Golgi cells. It receives excitatory input from the mossy fibers. They end on the dendrites of the granule cells and these complexes are called glomeruli. The axon from the granule cells travels to the molecular layer and bifurcates in a T-shape. These branches form the T and are called parallel fibers. These parallel fibers form excitatory synapses with the Purkinje cells. The granule cells form the only excitatory neurons in the cerebellar cortex. Golgi cells receive input from parallel fibers and mossy fibers. They send inhibitory output to the granule cells.

Neurotransmitters released:

  • Stellate, basket, Golgi and Purkinje cells- GABA
  • Granule cells - Glutamate

The only output from the cerebellar cortex is inhibitory from the Purkinje cells to the deep cerebellar nuclei.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents with ataxia-telangiectasia. Which of the following is an excitatory cell lost in this disorder?
questions.solution:
Ataxia-telangiectasia is characterized by progressive neuronal degeneration with a loss of Purkinje and granule cells in the cerebellum. The granule cells are the only excitatory cells in the cerebellar cortex.

questions.text: A man presented with tremors caused due to progressive degeneration of the cells that form the output of the cerebellar cortex. Which of the following cells are affected?
questions.solution:
The tremors are caused due to progressive degeneration of the Purkinje cells that form the output of the cerebellar cortex. They form the only output neurons of the cerebellar cortex.

The output of the whole cerebellum is from the deep cerebellar nuclei namely fastigial, globose, emboliform and dentate.

questions.text: The following slide from a rabies patient shows inclusion bodies in the Purkinje cells receiving input from:
questions.solution:
The given slide shows Negri bodies, which are eosinophilic, cytoplasmic inclusions found in the neurons of the Purkinje cells in a patient with rabies. The input to the Purkinje cells of the cerebellum come from the climbing fibers.

The image given below shows Negri bodies.

Related Pearl: Cerebellar Circuitry

Cerebellar circuitry includes:

Afferents- Climbing and mossy fibers

  • Climbing fibers -
    • Origin - contralateral inferior olivary nucleus in the medulla oblongata
    • Terminates on - Purkinje cell
  • Mossy fibers -
    • Origin - multiple sources in the spinal cord and brainstem
    • Terminates on - Granule cell

Intrinsic components

  • Granule cell backward inhibition - done by Golgi cells- prevent transmission from mossy fibers to the granule cells
  • Purkinje cells forward inhibition- done by stellate and basket cells

Efferents -

  • The output from the cerebellar cortex - from Purkinje cells inhibitory output to the deep cerebellar nuclei
  • The output from the cerebellum - from deep cerebellar nuclei
    • Globose, emboliform, and dentate - via superior cerebellar peduncle
    • Fastigial - via inferior cerebellar peduncle

questions.text: A patient recovering from COVID-19 presented with sudden onset slurred speech and difficulty walking. On examination, cerebellar signs are positive. What is true about the affected circuitry?

choices.text: Climbing and mossy fibers are inhibitory and use GABA as the neurotransmitter.
Mossy fibers end by forming a synapse with dendrites of Purkinje cells.
All climbing fibers originate from the contralateral inferior olivary nucleus.
Efferent fibers from all the cerebellar nuclei leave the cerebellum through superior cerebellar peduncle.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute viral cerebellitis secondary to COVID-19. The true statement regarding the cerebellar circuitry is that that all climbing fibres originate from the contralateral inferior olivary nucleus.

Option A: Climbing and mossy fibers are excitatory and use glutamate and aspartate as the neurotransmitters.

Option B: Mossy fibers terminate on the granule cells forming glomeruli. 

Option D: Efferents of the cerebellum pass through the superior and inferior cerebellar peduncles.

questions.text: Purkinje cells of cerebellum relay into _______
questions.solution:
Purkinje cells of the cerebellum relay into the dentate nucleus which is one of the deep cerebellar nuclei.

The input to the Purkinje cells come from the climbing fibres. The output of Purkinje cells is inhibitory to the deep cerebellar nuclei.

Options A and B: Caudate and lentiform nuclei are part of the basal ganglia. 

Option D: Red nucleus receives afferents from the cerebellum and plays a role in modulating signals to the upper motor neurons of the cerebral cortex.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with glioblastoma multiforme involving the inferior cerebellar peduncle. All of the following tracts may be involved by the tumor except:
questions.solution:
The anterior spinocerebellar tract does not pass through the inferior cerebellar peduncle. It enters the cerebellum through the superior cerebellar peduncle.

Glioblastoma multiforme is the most malignant and frequently occurring type of primary astrocytomas. It has the worst long-term prognosis (median survival of roughly 1 year).

questions.text: Fibers from the marked structure terminate at which of the following?
questions.solution:
The peduncle highlighted in the image is the superior cerebellar peduncle. The superior cerebellar peduncle includes fibers from deep cerebellar nuclei that project to the brainstem, red nucleus, and thalamus. It also contains the ventral spinocerebellar tract fibers.

The superior cerebellar peduncle contains all the efferent fibers from the dentate, emboliform, and the globose nuclei, and a small fascicle from the fastigial nucleus. Its fibers decussate in the caudal mesencephalon and are destined to synapse in the contralateral red nucleus and thalamus. The middle cerebellar peduncle contains only afferent fibers from the contralateral pontine nuclei. The inferior cerebellar peduncle is a mixture of afferent fibers from the brainstem and spinal cord and efferent fibers to the vestibular nuclei.

The image below summarizes the various tracts in the cerebellar unit.

The cerebellum consists of two hemispheres (right and left) joined by a median vermis. It is divided into three lobes:-

  • Anterior lobe - lies superiorly above the primary fissure
  • Middle lobe - lies inferiorly below the primary fissure. It is the largest lobe. It is also called the posterior lobe.
  • Flocculonodular lobe - lies posterior to the uvulonodular fissure

It has two surfaces - superior and inferior separated by a horizontal fissure. It is connected to the other parts of the central nervous system via three peduncles

  • Superior cerebellar peduncle -connecting to the midbrain
  • Middle cerebellar peduncle - connecting to the pons
  • Inferior cerebellar peduncle - connecting to the medulla oblongata

questions.text: A patient presented with clinical features of ataxia and incoordination. This is due to thrombosis of which artery?
questions.solution:
Thrombosis of the superior cerebellar artery causes cerebellar lesion which presents with ataxia and incoordination.

 Blood supply of cerebellum: 

  • Superior cerebellar artery
  • Posterior inferior cerebellar artery
  • Anterior inferior cerebellar artery
